_prev_prog_3.TR_OtherType: Periodic monthly training calls given by the Corporate Compliance Team
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Entire System mechanical integrity weekly inspection

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
C&S Wholesale Grocers' senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but to also maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding community.  The Corporate Compliance Team assists the facility in administering safety and environmental policies. The Corporate Compliance Team is made up of the following personnel:

-	Senior Managers of Refrigeration
-	Director of Environmental & OSHA Compliance

The Maintenance Manager periodically evaluates the health and safety practices of facility employees to ensure compliance, and oversees implementation of the safety and environmental programs.  These programs include forklift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturer's documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

C&S - Aberdeen is located at 1000 Old Philadelphia Road in Aberdeen, Maryland, which is approximately 1 ½ miles south-east of the I-95.  The area immediately surrounding the facility is rural. The maximum intended inventory of ammonia at the C&S Wholesale Grocers Aberdeen, Maryland facility is approximately 52,000 pounds within the refrigeration system. The refrigeration system uses anhydrous ammonia to provide refrigeration for dock operations, freezer and cold storage warehousing, an underfloor glycol system, and ice making operations.

Off-site Release Scenarios

C&S has conducted an OCA based on the EPA document titled "RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines," and used the EPA's RMP*Comp Version 1.07 to estimate the distance traveled to a toxic endpoint defined by the EPA regulation. This data were then used to estimate the potential impact caused by a release from each of the regulated substances.
Worst-Case Release Scenarios
As required by regulations, scenarios were considered where the entire capacity of the larg

est vessel for each regulated chemical at the facility was released in 10 minutes. Although these scenarios are highly unlikely in the event of a release, it provides the local responding agencies with a maximum possible impact in the event of an accidental release. In considering these releases, the most pessimistic meteorological conditions were used. Passive mitigation measures were taken into account when considering these release scenarios.
Alternative Release Scenarios
Alternative scenarios were developed to assess what potential impact may occur in the event of a release that is more likely to occur than the worst-case scenarios for each of the regulated chemicals. Several possible release scenarios were considered, and the scenarios with the greatest offsite impact were chosen. In considering the alternative release scenario, the default meteorological conditions for alternative scenarios were used in RMP*Comp. These scenarios represent a more realistic release, and have a downwind distance and impact considerably smaller than the worst-case scenario. No passive or active mitigation measures were taken into account when considering these release scenarios.
 
Process Description

The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of liquid ammonia from the Condensers (6) to the Thermosyphon/ High Pressure Receiver (V-1).  A bevy located at the top of the vessel maintains a reservoir of liquid ammonia for thermosyphon oil cooling of the Compressors and any excess liquid overflows to the main storage portion of the vessel.  The Thermosyphon/ High-Pressure Receiver (V-1) feeds high-pressure liquid ammonia to the Intercooler (V-2) and the +15F Recirculator (V-5), as needed.  Excess liquid in the Intercooler (V-2) is transferred to the Thermosyphon/ High Pressure Receiver (V-1) via an associated Transfer Drum (V-3).

At the Intercooler (V-2), the high-pressure ammonia liquid is chilled as it passes through coils immersed in a bath of liquid ammonia located inside th

e vessel.  The resultant controlled pressure liquid then flows to the Low Temperature Recirculator (V-4).  A liquid float switch connected to the liquid inlet from the Thermosyphon/ High Pressure Receiver (V-1) maintains the level of the bath of ammonia within the Intercooler (V-2).  In the event of a high level situation within the Intercooler (V-2) liquid can be transferred back to the Thermosyphon/ High Pressure Receiver (V-1) via the Transfer Drum (V-3). The transfer cycle is initiated when a three-way valve, which vents vapor in the Transfer Drum (V-3) back to the Intercooler (V-2) during normal operation, closes the vent line and allows hot gas to pressurize the Transfer Drum (V-3) before pumping the liquid back to the Thermosyphon/ High Pressure Receiver (V-1). The Booster Compressors discharge to the Intercooler and the High Stage Compressors draw suction from it.

The Low Temperature Recirculator (V-4) pumps liquid ammonia to Evaporators located within the "New Side" Freezer   which includes -10/+50F Bakery Freezer [AU-1N thru AU-21N as well as AU-5 thru AU-12 on the "Old Side" Freezer].  The ammonia, flowing through coils located within the Evaporator units, partially boils as it removes heat from the product and room.  The resultant liquid/ vapor mix from each evaporator is routed back to the same vessel.  The liquid droplets fall to the bottom of the vessel, while the Booster Compressors draw the vapor from the top of the vessel.

The +15F Recirculator (V-5) sends liquid ammonia to the -30F Recirculator (V-6) and to Evaporators located within the, +32F Dock, +45F Corridor, and the Ice Room Evaporators as well as all high temperature evaporators on "New" and "Old" side.  The ammonia, flowing through coils located within the Evaporator units, partially boils as it removes heat from the product and room.  The resultant liquid/ vapor mix from each evaporator is routed back to the same vessel.  The liquid droplets fall to the bottom of the vessel, while the I

ce Room Compressors draw the vapor from the top of the vessel. The Intercooler (V-2) supplies chilled liquid ammonia to the three ice making machines (IM-1 thru IM-3) in the Ice Room. The ice making machines utilize hot gas defrost from Ice Room Compressors via the old Thermosyphon/High Pressure receiver from the original system.  This vessel is now referred to as the Balance Tank (V-7). The Ice Makers return suction to the suction Accumulator (V-8). 

-30F Recirculator (V-6) feeds AU-1 thru AU-4 (the "Old" Freezer) and AU-2A and AU-3A. The ammonia, flowing through coils located within the Evaporator units, partially boils as it removes heat from the product and room.  The resultant liquid/ vapor mix from each evaporator is routed back to the same vessel.  The liquid droplets fall to the bottom of the vessel, while the Booster Compressors draw the vapor from the top.

The Ice Room Compressors draw suction from the Ice Maker Suction Accumulator (V-8) and any excess liquid is fed to the booster discharge line which then ends up in the Intercooler (V-2).  There are also evaporators located in the Battery Charging Area and Maintenance Area that are used to heat those spaces when the ambient temperature drops below a comfortable limit (+70F).  High stage discharge is condensed as it releases heat to the room.  The resultant condensate drains to the +15F Recirculator (V-5).

The Suction Accumulator (V-8) has an associated transfer vessel, the Ice Maker Suction Accumulator Transfer Vessel (V-10). The purpose of the Ice Maker Suction Accumulator Transfer Vessel (V-10) is to remove the excess liquid ammonia from the Ice Maker Suction Accumulator (V-8).  The transfer cycle is initiated when a three-way valve, which vents vapor in the Transfer Vessel (V-10) to the Intercooler (V-2) via the booster discharge line. During normal operation, the three-way valve closes the vent line and allows Compressor discharge to pressurize the Transfer Vessel before pumping the liquid back to

the Intercooler (V-2).

The Booster Compressors (BC-1 & BC-2) draw low stage suction from the Low Temperature Recirculator (V-4) and the -30F Recirculator (V-6) and discharge to the Intercooler (V-2).  The low stage Compressors on the "Old" side (RC-4 & RC-5) draw suction from the Low Temperature Recirculator (V-4) and the -30F Recirculator (V-6) and discharge to the Condensers.  The Ice Room Compressors (RC-2 & RC-3) draw suction from the Ice Maker Suction Accumulator (V-8), raise the pressure of the gas, and then discharge to the Condensers.  The High Stage Compressors (HS-1, HS-2 and RC-01) draw high stage suction from the Intercooler (V-2) and +15F Recirculator (V-5) and discharge to the Condensers.  All Compressors receive high-pressure liquid ammonia from the Thermosyphon/ High Pressure Receiver (V-1) for oil cooling purposes.  At the Condensers, air and water is used to condense the high-pressure gas into high-pressure liquid, which then drains to the Thermosyphon/ High Pressure Receiver (V-1) to begin the refrigeration cycle again.

High Stage Compressor discharge is also used in the defrost cycle of the Evaporators and in the Glycol Underfloor Heat Exchangers.  Glycol, used in a separate closed system, is heated by high pressure ammonia vapor as it passes through the Heat Exchangers.  The ammonia condenses to a liquid and then drains to the +15F Recirculator (V-5).  

The system is also equipped with two Automatic Purgers for removal of non-condensables, i.e. air, from the system. Ammonia sensors are located in the Engine Room and within refrigerated spaces throughout the perishable and freezer warehouse.  

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

In order to operate the ammonia refrigeration system, the facility complies with the following risk management regulations:

1)  OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM); and
2)  EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP).

These regulations impose numerous requirements on the facility

to ensure the safety of the public and on-site workers.  The following summarizes the key compliance programs that have been implemented by C&S - Aberdeen to prevent the accidental release of ammonia from the facility.  The Operating Procedures program ensures that the ammonia system is operated in a safe manner.  The Training program ensures that personnel fully understand how to perform their jobs in a safe manner.  The Mechanical Integrity program ensures that the ammonia system is in proper working condition based upon routine testing, inspections, and maintenance according to manufacturer's specifications and industry standards.  The Management of Change program ensures that process modifications are implemented in a safe manner.  The Pre-Startup Safety Review program ensures that adequate safety measures are in place before ammonia is introduced into a process.  The Hot Work Permit program ensures that C&S - Aberdeen's employees and contractors perform hot work (e.g. welding) in a safe manner.  The Contractor Safety program ensures that contractors understand the hazards of ammonia and must take specified precautions to safely complete job requirements.

It is important to note that the refrigeration system has been designed with several safety features to prevent the accidental release of ammonia.  For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits.  Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled.  The facility has also installed ammonia sensors in the Engine Room which will alert operators in the event of a low-level ammonia detection and cease operation of the refrigeration system in the event of a high-level detection.  There are also ammonia detectors located throughout the freezer warehouse that will alert operators in

the event of an ammonia detection in those locations.  An off-site alarm company monitors the ammonia detection system while the facility is unmanned.  In the event of a release while the facility is unmanned, the off-site alarm company will notify the Maintenance Manager and Refrigeration Technicians.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no significant releases of ammonia at the Facility in the last five years (June 2019 - June 2024) of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility has an Emergency Action Plan (plan) in effect at the facility.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:  
- save lives;
- minimize and avoid injuries;
- protect the environment; and
- minimize property damage.

The Plan provides the notification procedures and evacuation routes for emergencies that may arise at the facility. The Facility is non-responding and has personnel trained to support the HazMat response team if required (up to 300 ppm of ammonia).
There is a specific program (CEHS-0042) which outlines the training, qualifications and procedures for authorized ammonia Incident responders and observers.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations.  Facility personnel receive annual training regarding the emergency procedures and the Emergency Response Team holds regular drills.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

In April 1999, the refrigeration system was thoroughly examined for safety hazards by way of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).  In addition, three Revalidations of the Process Hazard Analysis have been conducted as follows:
Previous studies have been conducted at the facility as follows [40 CFR 68.67(a)].

- Original Study -4/19/1999
- PHA Revalidation 1 - 11/4/2003
- PHA Revalidation 2 - 9/16/2008
- PHA Revalidation 3 - 9/9/2013 & 9/10/2013
- PHA Revalidation 4 - 5/3/2017 & 5/4/2017
- PHA Revalidation 5 - 1/20/2022 &

1/21/2022

The PHA Revalidations consisted of:

- Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study or What-If Studies
- series of safety checklists; and
- facility inspection.

The mitigation measures (recommendations) include additional training, key maintenance-related tests/inspection, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures.  The recommendations resultant from the most recent revalidation study are scheduled to be addressed by 1/20/2024.
